description.narrative:
Det övergripande utvecklingsmålet för ProDem är att ”Minska fattigdom och öka välbefinnande för kvinnor och män som bor i kommuner i norra delen av Mocambique”. Det specifika målet för programmet är att “Bidra till minskad urban fattigdom, samt uthållig utveckling av kommuner genom ett stärkt kommunalt styre och förbättrad service till innevånarna; samt ökad motståndskraft mot klimatförändringar, samt stärkt ansvarsutkrävande och deltagande”.
ProDem kommer bidra till att öka intäkter för kommunerna och till stärkt finansiell styrning. En särskild metodik för deltagande och ansvarsutkrävande, kallad Munisam, kommer att tillämpas. Mocambique har en stor brist på infrastruktur och så även i den lokala miljön. ProDem kommer därför att bidra till investeringar för att stärka den miljömässiga uthålligheten, bland annat genom förbättrad sophantering och stärkt resiliens. För att stärka koordinering och policyutveckling, är detta kombinerat med stöd till strategiskt viktiga områden på nationell nivå, samt med stöd till organisationen för samarbete mellan kommuner, ANAMM. ProDem täcker 50% av kommunerna i landet och har nära samarbete med andra program för utveckling av kommuner, vilket bidrar till nationell samordning.
Avtalsupplägget i ProDem bygger på att givarna (Sverige, Danmark, Irland och Schweiz) delegerar genomförandet till Danmark, som är ”lead agent” och kommer ha alla kontraktuella förbindelser med de genomförande organisationerna. Danmark åtar sig genom ett samfinansieringsavtal att upphandla en konsult. Danmark förmedlar medel till den konsult, vilken handhar finansiell hantering, resultatuppföljning, styrning och teknisk assistans. Konsulten sluter avtal med de kommuner som kommer genomföra investeringar och de övriga organisationer som kommer bidra till programmets genomförande. En mindre del av finansieringen (ca 6%) planeras gå till Mocambiques regering för genomförande av programaktiviteter.
Initial tid för insatsen är två och ett halvt år, men både projektdokumentet och kontraktet med den genomförande konsulten är sammansatta så att en förlängning på två år, upp till totalt fyra och ett halvt år, ses som ett naturligt steg efter att en halvtidsutvärdering gjorts.

The overall Immediate Objective of PRODEM is “Contribute to urban poverty reduction and sustainable development of the municipalities, through improvements in municipal governments administration and service delivery, resilience to climate change impact, social accountability and citizen’s participation”
ProDem puts an emphasis on increased revenues for the municipalities, and on improved financial management. A special methodology for participation and accountability will be applied, the Munisam. Mozambique has a lack of infrastructure in the local environment. ProDem will contribute to improved resilience, environmental sustainability, and to improved waste management. In order to strengthen coordination and policy development at ministerial level, the ProDem will contribute to strategically important areas at with a national coverage, and will support also the organisation for municipal cooperation ANAMM. ProDem will cover 50% of the municipalities in the country, and has close cooperation with other similar programmes, contributing to coordination between these.
The government of Mozambique has requested that donor partners support the process to develop and strengthen municipalities. In ProDem, the donors (Sweden, Ireland and Switzerland) will delegate implementation to Denmark, which will be the lead agent and have all contractual relations with the implementing organisations. Via a Joint Financing Agreement Denmark will be obligated to procure a consultant (the Service Provider). A basket fund is created via a bank account under control of Denmark. The basket fund will transfer funds to the Service Provider that will do financial management, results management, general management and technical assistance, and to the government. The Service Provider will enter into agreement with all municipalities that will implement investments and the other organisations that will contribute to the implementation of the programme. A lesser part (approx. 6%) of the financing will be executed by the Government via the Single Treasury AccountThe Joint Financing Agreement (JFA) will constitute the contribution agreement, and is built on the templates and intentions in the Nordic Plus arrangement. Initial time for the contribution is two and a half years, but both the project document and the contract with the implementing consultant are designed to allow an extension of two years, up to four and a half years, which is seen as a natural step after a mid-term review have been undertaken. In addition to the JFA there will be a Memorandum of Understanding between donors and the Government of Mozambique.

The Objective of PRODEM was to contribute to urban poverty reduction and sustainable development of the municipalities, through improvements in municipal governments’ administration and service delivery, resilience to climate change impact, social accountability and citizen’s participation”. The program worked through three components: Component A: Urban Management for Climate Resilience including climate-resilient land use planning and solid waste management. Component B: Public Financial Management, including Simplified Municipal Management System SGM-S; participatory budgeting; establishment of procurement units (UGEA) and internal control units (UCIF) and establishment of tax registers. Component Component C: Municipal Governance and Citizens’ Participation through support to participatory planning systems and processes. The programme was funded by the governments of Sweden, Denmark (lead donor), Switzerland and Ireland.

description.narrative: Mozambique is a much-centralised country, were political and economic power in practise is concentrated to a small group of people, which underpins the current situation with gradually increasing conflict. Therefore, decentralisation is the most important response, as a way to start sharing power and resources among broader layers of the population. ProDem was built on previous programmes that have been going on for at least ten years – first the P13 and after that the PDA. Drivers of the previous programmes were Denmark, Ireland, Switzerland and Austria, while for PRODEM are driven by Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark and Ireland. The bearing idea of ProDem was to provide funds for investment to 26 municipalities in the centre-north of the country, and by that PFM systems, planning systems and popular participation would be strengthened. And in the longer term, the idea was that the municipality could function as a nursery for democratic participation, fostering new leaders and political parties, which would eventually find their way up to the national structures. In terms of results achieved during the three years of the implementation, the programme enhanced the capacity of elected municipal leaders and technical staff to plan and implement infrastructure projects and develop municipal plans in the areas of climate resilience, solid waste management and municipal finance. In sum, the program has contributed to: - Improvement of Sustainable Urban Solid Waste Management Systems. - Increase the municipal revenues and transparent financial management. - Greater engagement of citizens aware of their civic rights and duties, capable of demanding accountability from municipal governments. - Further strengthening of ANAMM in its role as representative of the interests of municipalities. - Strengthened and improved national municipal framework for capacity building of municipal authorities and teams. - Municipal technicians, mayors and members of Municipal Councils and Assemblies have enhanced their technical and managerial capacity to plan and implement projects within the four thematic areas of PRODEM via the funding provided accompanied by on-the-job training as well as seminars, workshops and formalized training sessions - More men and women in vulnerable neighborhoods were mobilized and organized to participate in municipal planning and budgeting and awareness was raised on their rights and duties to hold municipal government accountable. - Projects supported in the 26 municipalities comprised in many cases a variety of initiatives within a single component, with municipalities being successful able to increase the revenue collection rate of own source revenues, etc. - In the component for Climate Resilient Urban Planning projects would often consist of the plan preparation, its implementation and capacity building as separately budgeted subprojects. - Infrastructure projects had a separate design phase and a construction phase with separate budgets. Likewise, in the Solid Waste Management component Integrated Solid Urban Waste Management Plans consisted in many cases of several subprojects like preparation of plan, landfill rehabilitation, equipment acquisition, training etc. - Through the support provided to the ministries, PRODEM contributed to the process of formulating the National Municipal Development Framework and revising the legal and normative instruments within PRODEM’s thematic areas. - By the end of the programme implementation, 206 projects were fully implemented and another 68 projects partially implemented. In terms of studies and publications, the program was able to carry out 1 Mid-Term Evaluation, 3 PRAG (Peer Review Advisory Group) missions to evaluate the implementation stage and compliance with established goals, as well as numerous case studies to document the implementation of the program. Some of the technical documents produced may are: - Manual of the Course of Management of Solid Waste for IMPFA (Training Institute for Physical Planning and Environment). - Training Manual on Climate Resilient Urban Planning. - Training Manual for the preparation of the PGIRSU (Integrated Urban Solid Waste Management Plan). - Training Manual for Elaboration of Equipment Maintenance Plan. An unexpected event, which undermined the program implementation and extension, was the Danish government decision to end its development cooperation with a number of countries, including Mozambique and close its embassy in Maputo. The decision to close the Danish Embassy led to a long discussion about SDC taking over the role as Lead JFA-partner. In July 2017 the Swiss Embassy, however, informed its JFA-partners that SDC would not take over the lead donor role. Denmark continued to operate the JFA-account and managed the TA-contract with COWI, but some of the Lead JFA-partner functions suffered from the uncertainties associated with the closing of the Danish Embassy. Other unexpected results were the delay in sigining the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government, COWI and donors. This had huge impact in quick start the program.
